description.plain:
According to Oh Pep!’s website,

A sense of light and dark stitches together the tapestry of Stadium Cake, continually bringing a sense of tension to each song. It’s heard in the texture of “Tea, Milk and Honey,” as Hally sings with sparse accompaniment before the delayed entry of the band.

song.title: Tea, Milk & Honey

annotatable.link_title: Tea, Milk & Honey by Oh Pep!
annotatable.title: Tea, Milk & Honey

body.plain:
According to Oh Pep!’s website,

A sense of light and dark stitches together the tapestry of Stadium Cake, continually bringing a sense of tension to each song. It’s heard in the texture of “Tea, Milk and Honey,” as Hally sings with sparse accompaniment before the delayed entry of the band.

annotations:
She don’t read the news on the TV
 Tea, milk and honey never satisfy me

Her lover isn’t interested in informing herself on current events and the deeper things in life and though she loves her lover, this is a problem for Olivia. Olivia cannot be satisfied by sugar-coated surface-level stuff. She needs a more hearty meal, and her lover cannot be that for her.
She wakes up early and she leaves too soon
This suggests that her lover isn’t as invested in their relationship as she is. She is always slipping out – presumably while she is sleeping – and doesn’t stay as long as Olivia wants her to.
She sings like a church with a choir in it

This phrasing makes her ‘baby’ larger than just a church choir and gives it a deeper meaning. The lover is  raised up to being something holy because they are the church. The choir inside the church is meant to show how powerful her voice is, because she embodies multiple voices at once.

search_results.lyrics:
25 Lyrics[Verse 1]
On the eve of my 25th birthday
You come knocking at my door at night
I tried to hole in my head, a hole in my pocket
Nothing makes me feel as high
There's a silhouette of your body
In the dim of the hallway light

[Pre Chorus]
You move left (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
I move right (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
[Chorus 1]
Lordy knows you're still turning me on
Holding heavy hands with heavy hearts
The craze on the building inside
Distract the people, suspending them mid-flight
And realize that they will miss the ones they love
When they know death


[Verse 2]
The light in my room goes on at 3:30
I take a bath because I feel dirty
The power goes out and I lay in the dark in the water
I'm running my legs across the surface
I'm in debt and I am nervous
It came out of my pause in the way I move my eyes
If I stare in one place for more than 3 seconds
I calm down and my heartbeat lessens
It's quiet outside, except for the roll of the thunder

[Chorus 1]
Lordy knows you're still turning me on
Holding heavy hands with heavy hearts
The craze on the building inside
Distract the people, suspending them mid-flight
And realize that they will miss the ones they love
When they know death

Holding heavy hands with heavy hearts
The craze on the building inside
Distract the people, suspending them mid-flight
And realize that they will miss the ones they love
When they know death (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
When they know death (Nothing ever prepared me for this)

[Verse 3]
On the eve of my 26th birthday
You come knocking on my door at night
I tried to hole in my head, a hole in my pocket
Nothing makes me feel as high
As the silhouette of your body
In the dim of the hallway light

[Pre-Chorus]
You move left (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
I move right (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
You move left (Nothing ever prepared me for this)
I move right (Nothing ever prepared me for this)Embed

description.plain:
According to Oh Pep!’s website,

“Doctor Doctor,” the album’s first single, is a pop song with elements of the unexpected, revealing the band’s interest in experimental and occasionally dissonant melodies as Hally sings “Where is the light, for me it’s the darkest night.”

description.plain:
Most of Oh Pep!’s tracks were written on guitar, but she and Doug Schadt (Maggie Rogers, The Middle) composed “Hurt Nobody” on the piano during a “bomb cyclone” storm in Manhattan. A spacious, mid-tempo lament, it’s haunted by the mantra “I’m coming undone.” “There was this underlying eeriness that day. The energy was apocalyptic, because we were snowed in,” Olivia explains. “One way of describing the song is that we were in a very warm room, but there was a mad storm outside.”
-Grandstand HQ

song.embed_content: Read “Hurt Nobody” by Oh Pep! on Genius
song.title: Hurt Nobody

body.plain:
Most of Oh Pep!’s tracks were written on guitar, but she and Doug Schadt (Maggie Rogers, The Middle) composed “Hurt Nobody” on the piano during a “bomb cyclone” storm in Manhattan. A spacious, mid-tempo lament, it’s haunted by the mantra “I’m coming undone.” “There was this underlying eeriness that day. The energy was apocalyptic, because we were snowed in,” Olivia explains. “One way of describing the song is that we were in a very warm room, but there was a mad storm outside.”
-Grandstand HQ

annotations: This line is contradicted by the next song, wherein she sings, “I know that I am mean.”

description.plain:
Her travels, from summer 2017 to early 2018, shaped the songwriting. Olivia wrote most of the exquisitely harmonic “Your Nail and Your Hammer”-its title inspired by words written on her wall-in Nashville, influenced by the city’s love of Americana.
-Grandstand HQ

Now I'm coming up for air

You were standing on the sand

You make the distance greater still
But I've got a thirst for thrill
It is the worst, it's cursed, it's hard to kill

So I swallow the pill
Which makes the distance greater still
But I've got a thirst for thrill
If you don't it want it, it's certain that I willYou might also likeEmbed

description.plain:
From Bob Billen, writing for NPR’s First Watch:

There’s an underlying tension in this languid tune by Oh Pep! that glues the song together. “Crazy Feels,” is a song by one of my favorite Australian bands is about how we navigate boundaries in relationships. Those boundaries and constraints are represented in this video quite literally — by boxes, illustrated by digital artist Sergio Pastore, who told us via email that the lyrics were key to inspiring his illustrations: “The storyline, and the way the characters interact,” he writes, “clearly reflects the relationship difficulties of our times.” His “choice of colors, but also the background design” mirror the song’s tense balance.

song.embed_content: Read “Crazy Feels” by Oh Pep! on Genius
song.title: Crazy Feels

body.plain:
From Bob Billen, writing for NPR’s First Watch:

There’s an underlying tension in this languid tune by Oh Pep! that glues the song together. “Crazy Feels,” is a song by one of my favorite Australian bands is about how we navigate boundaries in relationships. Those boundaries and constraints are represented in this video quite literally — by boxes, illustrated by digital artist Sergio Pastore, who told us via email that the lyrics were key to inspiring his illustrations: “The storyline, and the way the characters interact,” he writes, “clearly reflects the relationship difficulties of our times.” His “choice of colors, but also the background design” mirror the song’s tense balance.
